name: NHL 25 Defensive Pressure System Tree
description: Canonical defensive pressure tree using ONLY NHL 25 in-game options: Protect Net, Contain Puck, Normal, Puck Side Attack, and High Pressure. Each option includes strengths, weaknesses, when to use it, and matchup tags.

notes: All pressure options must match NHL 25 UI EXACTLY.
Matchup outputs must only recommend these settings.
In-game adjustments and full gameplans derive from this file.

Protect Net.label: Protect Net
Protect Net.description: Ultra-conservative pressure style that collapses to the slot and net-front to prevent high-danger chances.
strengths: Best for defending leads late in games.
Shuts down slot passes, net drives, and crease chaos.
Excellent vs teams that funnel everything to the middle.
weaknesses: Gives opponents more space on the perimeter.
Not good when you need turnovers to generate offense.

recommended_usage.tied_game: Use situationally vs heavy slot teams

Contain Puck.label: Contain Puck
Contain Puck.description: Structured, conservative pressure style that contains puck carriers toward the boards without overcommitting.
strengths: Controls the pace of the game.
Excellent vs east-west passers like Kane, Marner, Zegras.
Prevents seam passes through the middle.
weaknesses: Does not create many turnovers on its own.
May allow teams to cycle longer.

Normal.label: Normal
Normal.description: Balanced pressure option with equal parts containment and challenge. A good middle-ground setting.
strengths: Useful when you don't want to bias too heavily toward caution or aggression.
Good for general 5v5 where you want flow both ways.
weaknesses: Not specialized enough for elite opponents.
Can be outmatched by heavy cycle or high-skill rush teams.

Puck Side Attack.label: Puck Side Attack
Puck Side Attack.description: Aggressive pressure setting that attacks the puck carrier directly on the strong side.
strengths: Creates turnovers high in the zone.
Excellent vs uncertain defenders and bad passers (e.g. Petry, Holl).
weaknesses: Risky if opponent has elite passers (Kane, McDavid, Hughes).

High Pressure.label: High Pressure
High Pressure.description: Maximum pressure setting. Defender pinches quickly, forwards pressure hard, and the team attempts to force turnovers immediately.
strengths: Great for late-game comebacks or momentum swings.
weaknesses: High risk of getting beat on cross-ice plays.
Can break structure vs elite rush teams.

recommended_usage.tied_game: Use carefully when momentum is needed

notes: Default to Protect Net in final 5 minutes.
Contain Puck is safer in earlier stages of protecting a lead.
Use Contain Puck vs pass-heavy opponents.
Use Normal vs balanced or depth-based competition.
Use Puck Side Attack if opponent has weak defenders.
Use High Pressure late in the game when you need immediate impact.

opponent_style_based.why: Prevents slot seams and wall-to-middle attacks.
Attacks cycle structure and forces early turnovers.
Keeps structure intact and limits foot races.
Forces mistakes and breaks the breakout early.

dz_strategy.note: Defensive Pressure works in tandem with DZ Strategy (Collapsing, Staggered, Tight Point). A separate Canon file will define DZ Strategy behaviors.
